Felicity Lawrence's uncovering of the brutal conditions faced by migrant workers (Happy hens, unhappy workers? Gangmasters face abuse claim, 30 October) is a sobering reminder that not everyone enjoys the humane treatment at work that most people take for granted. Thank goodness, then, for the Gangmasters Licensing Authority that put a stop to this abuse.

Most people would conclude that its powers should be increased to stop more companies from trafficking and abusing workers.

Not this government. The Beecroft report deemed moves to tackle trafficking to be "burdensome" red tape and called for "serious consideration" to be given to abolishing the GLA. Ministers backed down under union pressure but, by allowing gangmasters to set up without proper checks, this government has made GLA's work in making free range chickens free from human abuse harder.
Sarah Veale
Head of equality and employment rights, TUC

• There are many reasons why farmers want to see the abolition of the Agriculture Wages Board (AWB) that Polly Toynbee does not cover (Comment, 26 October). For a start – and perhaps most importantly – 41% of farmworkers earn above the industry minimums set by the AWB, and few skilled workers currently receive the AWB minimum wage.

Is she arguing that Labour's flagship National Minimum Wage Act 1998 is inadequate? With modern employment legislation, not least a national minimum wage and rules covering workers' rights, industrial relations and business management, farm managers have to pay competitive rates to attract and retain skills, just like any other business.

And the accusation that without the AWB farm managers are free to abuse child workers is both offensive and inaccurate. In fact, the case she mentions was investigated but saw no prosecution brought by either the GLA or child protection services.

The AWB has no place in a modern, forward-thinking farming industry. The NFU already provides support to farmers and farm businesses on all aspects of employment relations and will build on this support for the farming community.
Meurig Raymond
Deputy president, NFU

The Guardian is to be congratulated for its forensic critique of government policy on Trident (Editorial, 30 October). In pointing out the compelling strategic, economic and moral arguments against Britain maintaining (let alone replacing) a nuclear weapons system, the absurdity of committing £100bn to Trident replacement is laid bare.

But there is one further argument which needs to be made here: scrapping Trident is a vote winner – and this is something Labour and the Lib Dems must understand.

The case must be made in no uncertain terms: would the public rather have essential services or a redundant weapons system? Do the military want usable equipment or an outmoded totem? And does the world need another hypocritical nuclear-armed state paying lip service to disarmament while ploughing billions into its nuclear arsenal?

Domestically and internationally, Britain should be bold in rejecting nuclear weapons. They're indefensible and worthless – and who would want to defend that?
Kate Hudson
General secretary, Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament

• Why do not opponents of Trident take the straightforward, compelling and unanswerable stance that it is not Britain's to use? Trident's guidance system is controlled by the US, and the notion that Washington is going to allow its erstwhile colonial rulers to choose a target for such a devastating WMD is outside the realms of reality.

The origins of this ludicrous situation go back to Trident's predecessor, Polaris, on which Harold Macmillan and his close ally John F Kennedy made a deal at Nassau in 1962 for Britain to have a figleaf arrangement, masquerading as independent control, in order to assuage backbench Tory outrage over the US's unilateral abandonment of the Skybolt missile that was to be used in RAF bombers. Skybolt was flawed, but it would at least have been an independent system. Trident is the opposite.

Your leader, Nick Clegg's criticisms, Polly Toynbee's Comment piece and Martin Rowson's typically brilliant cartoon all missed the chance to nail the pretence that Trident is independent.
John Webster
London

• Trident is neither British nor independent, and it isn't much of a deterrent. And hardly a bargain. Evidence to the Commons defence select committee demonstrated that Trident depends crucially for launch and target acquisition data on US military GPS satnav. You can be sure that if we tried to do something the White House didn't approve, the satnav would be switched off.
Peter Johnston
Bolton, Lancashire

• In 1986, the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, said: "The accident at Chernobyl showed again what an abyss will open if nuclear war befalls mankind." He later said it was that accident that triggered the end of the cold war. As long as there are nuclear power stations in the world the deterrent value of nuclear weapons is illusory. In a nuclear war the real damage will be caused by uncontrollable emissions of radioactive material from nuclear reactors and their associated storage zones.

Britain has plenty of nuclear power stations. As the prevailing winds in Britain are southwesterly, the likely victims of any attack on us will be to our east: Russia and China, the presumed objects of Trident. They have nuclear power stations, too. If Trident were ever to be used, the entire northern hemisphere would become uninhabitable.
Craig Sams
Hastings, East Sussex

• Philip Hammond's go-ahead for Trident replacement (Tories snub Lib Dems over Trident future, 29 October) is just a ploy to scupper Scottish independence. It has nothing to do with being the "ultimate safeguard for Britain's security". The US has 14 Trident submarines and none of that killing power prevented the attacks on New York and the Pentagon. Billions of pounds of public money are to be spent on a dangerous, destabilising weapon that will only increase the risk of proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Rae Street
Littleborough, Lancashire

• The government claims a replacement for Trident is necessary for the creation of high-quality jobs and vital skills. This is profoundly depressing. To believe we have to invest in weapons of destruction is to totally ignore more peaceful and constructive investments, such as securing our energy needs through renewable energy or providing zero-carbon housing, hospitals and schools. We can develop high-quality jobs through ensuring a living wage, decent working hours, protection against unfair dismissal and so many other initiatives that this government considers unnecessary.
Jean Lambert MEP
Green, London

• Polly Toynbee and others should be urging Ed Miliband to make a referendum on the future of Trident a matter of Labour policy. This is an issue that concerns the kind of country (and world) we want our grandchildren to inherit; the spending priorities we want our politicians to attend to; and whether the kind of defence we want for our community needs to be quite so apocalyptic.

The debate and discussion around such an issue would be a collective airing of both the rational and irrational, and could return democracy back to where it belongs – our peoples. It might also be a fitting tribute to the resolution of the Cuban missile crisis from which, thank God, we all came through.
John Hills
Canterbury, Kent

• When is the Labour party going to stop being frightened of its own shadow on this issue? I fear that they, like the Tories, are seduced by big toys. We deserve better.
Alan Healey
Milson, Shropshire

The foundations of a spectacular Anglo-Saxon feasting hall, a place where a king and his warriors would have gathered for days of drinking and eating – as vividly described in the poem Beowulf – have been found inches below the village green of Lyminge in Kent.

There was one last celebration by the light of flickering flames at the site, 1,300 years after the hall was abandoned, as archaeologists marked the find by picking out the outline of the hall in candles, lighting up the end-of-excavation party. Heaps of animal bones buried in pits around the edge of the hall bore testimony to many epic parties of the past.

The unexpected find, by a team from the University of Reading funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council and working with local archaeologists and villagers, is exceptionally rare. Digging under the curious gaze of drinkers in the garden of the Coach and Horses pub a few metres away, it is the first great hall from the period to be discovered in more than 30 years.

At 21 metres by 8.5 metres, it would have been the most imposing structure for miles, large enough to hold at least 60 people. Beowulf, the most famous of all surviving Anglo-Saxon poems, describes the hero coming to just such a hall, Heorot – "the timbered hall / splendid and ornamented with gold. / The building in which that powerful man held court / Was the foremost of halls under heaven; / Its radiance shone over many lands."

The director of the Lyminge excavations, Gabor Thomas, said: "This would undoubtedly have been the scene of many Beowulfy type activities, great assemblies for feasts that lasted for days, much drinking and story-telling, rich gifts like arm rings being presented, all of that. There could have been no more visible sign of wealth and status than raising a hall like this."

The royal family and retinue would have visited sporadically. "This is before centralised tax collecting and coinage, too early for royal palaces as such," Thomas said. "To keep control you had to keep on the move, stopping at significant places, literally feeding off the land, off the rich food offerings that would be brought everywhere the king arrived."

Thomas believes the hall marks a crucial transition, the last flicker of the ancient pagan ways before the site was abandoned, after the hall had stood for perhaps no more than a generation.

A rare piece of beautifully decorated and gilded horse harness, broken in antiquity, was found in the foundations. It is the first such find from a domestic setting – similar examples are isolated finds by metal detectors, or from graves – and helps date the hall to the late sixth or early seventh century.

"The horse harness decoration is very significant," Thomas said. "It's not just a wonderful find, but evidence of the status of the people who used this site – the ability to own and upkeep a horse was the mark of the warrior aristocracy."

Other finds include pieces of jewellery, bone combs, and a remarkably well preserved manicure set – three little bronze rods, probably for cleaning fingernails or ears, strung on to a piece of wire. The site also yielded quantities of glass, some evidently scavenged by the Anglo-Saxons from nearby Roman sites and melted down to make glass bead jewellery.

Earlier excavations at various sites in the village, including the graveyard of the village church, which is said to have been founded in AD633 and to be the original burial place of St Ethelburga, uncovered evidence of thousands of years of habitation. The village is only a few miles from the Eurotunnel terminal, but is still surrounded by rich farmland, and remarkably isolated in a tangle of narrow country roads, hills and valleys.

Last summer, when the archaeologists moved on to the village green, which has been open land for almost 1,000 years, ground-penetrating radar suggested some structures lay beneath – but there was no hint of anything as significant as the hall.

The timbers are long gone, either rotted away or removed for reuse, but the outline of the huge building was clearly traced by post holes and the slots for planks laid horizontally to form the walls. It had a partitioned space at one end, either a sleeping place or a private chamber for the most aristocratic.

There is evidence that the building was at least damaged, if not destroyed, by fire – a common fate for timber buildings centred around open hearths – but Gabor believes the hall was deliberately abandoned as the tribe, as with the other Anglo-Saxons in Kent, turned to Christianity. The settlement was soon abandoned, too, and a new village grew higher on the hill around the new church – another lofty building, grander than any of its neighbours, which Thomas believes took on the role of the old pagan hall as the place for gatherings and celebrations. The archaeologists will return to Lyminge next summer. "There's more of this story," Thomas said.

HBOS executives threatened and swore at colleagues who were investigating the risks being taken by the bank before it collapsed in the financial crisis, it has been claimed.

Paul Moore, the former HBOS head of group regulatory risk who was sacked after raising concerns about the bank's management, made the claims during the latest session of the parliamentary commission on banking standards.

"When I tried to resolve the previous difficulties with Jo Dawson [HBOS group risk director 2004-2005 who eventually replaced Moore], she leant over the table – she stood up – pointed at me and said 'I'm warning you. Don't you make an effin' enemy out of me'," he said.

"It demonstrated that if a senior executive thought it was perfectly OK to speak to the head of regulatory risk in that tone you can imagine how the culture spreads through the organisation.

"It didn't matter what you were doing, if your job was to check people out, there was behaviour that was threatening and unpleasant to people doing these [risk assessment] activities".

Moore also said that HBOS was "worse than other environments [he'd] experienced", that "sales targets and bonuses [driven by former chief executive Sir James Crosby] were right at the heart" of the bank's collapse and that the board appointed Carphone Warehouse founder Charles Dunstone as head of the retail bank's risk control committee when he had "no technical expertise".

The comments are the latest from Moore on how he saw the collapse of the lender. In 2009 he told MPs he had been sacked for raising concerns about the lender's rapid growth in the years before the credit crunch while he has also submitted detailed reports to the Financial Services Authority on what went wrong. During Tuesday's appearance, he repeated many of his previous criticisms.

After his dismissal, a report into Moore's allegations – commissioned from the bank's auditors, KPMG – concluded that he lost his job because of personality clashes inside the lender in 2004 and not that Crosby sacked him because of warnings that HBOS was "going too fast" and "was a serious risk to financial stability and consumer protection".

Moore told the committee the accounting firm had concluded exactly what he expected. "The KPMG report said I was a lunatic and they were right – in summary," he said.

The committee also heard from Colin Matthew, the former chief executive of HBOS's international division, as well as Dawson.

Members did not ask her about the alleged exchanges with Moore, but she told them of how "one heard" rumours that HBOS's corporate bank – which was largely blamed for the bank's demise – was less cautious than competitors in giving loans, although she said she had "no ability to discern if people were jealous".

Dawson added: "We had an annual management conference every year, the top 500 or so coming. In 2006, I think it would have been, Sir Philip Green came as the guest speaker and … was very positive about [the HBOS corporate bank's] understanding of business."

The evidence came as the FSA prepares to kick off its own investigation into the collapse of HBOS.

In December, the City regulator published its report into the near-collapse of Royal Bank of Scotland, but had been delaying commencing its HBOS investigation until it had completed enforcement action against Peter Cummings, the former head of the bank's corporate division. Cummings was fined £500,000 and given a lifetime ban from the City in September.

Bahrain is facing international censure after announcing a ban on all protest gatherings and threatening to take legal action against opposition groups that organise anti-government demonstrations.

The order, announced by the interior ministry in Manama on Tuesday, is the most-far reaching attempt to quell unrest in the Gulf kingdom since martial law was imposed last year. It is a blow to the hopes of western countries trying to balance their own strategic and economic interests while encouraging peaceful reform.

Britain swiftly issued a statement expressing "concern" at what it called an "excessive" blanket ban.

Sheikh Rashid al-Khalifa, the interior minister, said that "repeated abuse" of the rights to freedom of speech and expression could no longer be tolerated. In future protests would only be permitted once security and stability were sufficient to maintain national unity.

Bahrain, where a Sunni minority rules over a Shia majority, is often described as lying on a sectarian fault line of the Arab world and on the frontline of a tense confrontation between Iran and its Gulf Arab neighbours.

The interior ministry said that any "illegal rally or gathering would be tackled through legal actions against those calling for and participating in it".

Bahraini observers said the move appeared to reflect divisions and hesitation within the government and the lack of dialogue between it and the opposition. "The situation is stagnant and there is no horizon for a political solution," said Mansoor al-Jamri, editor of al-Wasat newspaper. "They are tightening their grip, but this is not a crackdown. That will mean mass arrests and opening the jails and taking senior people into custody."

Bahrain has permitted limited protests and marches, but much of the violence occurs outside authorised gatherings.

Bahrain's brief chapter of the Arab spring – known to activists as the "Pearl Revolution" – ended last March, when the Saudis and other members of the Gulf Cooperation Council intervened to help restore order. But sporadic protests have continued and escalated in recent days.

The target of the warning appeared to be the largest Shia political bloc, al-Wefaq, which has organised many marches. Another rally was planned for Friday.

Al-Wefaq condemned the interior ministry order as breaching international law and human rights. The authorities had rejected a Wefaq request for a rally on Sunday evening at Akar, a village near the capital Manama where a bomb fatally wounded a policeman on October 18. The opposition movement then organised a licensed demonstration, but when people took to the streets, they chanted "Down with Hamad," a reference to the king.

A full crackdown on the opposition would anger the US, Britain and other western allies that have stood by the Bahraini since last year's unrest.

The US has important military links with Bahrain, which hosts the US Navy's 5th Fleet, but it has also called for increased efforts at dialogue to ease the tensions.

Britain has repeatedly called on Bahrain to implement the recommendations of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry, which issued its report last year.

"I am concerned that the government of Bahrain has decided to ban all rallies and public gatherings until further notice," said Alistair Burt, the UK foreign office minister. "We understand the government's concerns about maintaining law and order, especially when faced with increasingly violent protests, but a blanket ban of this nature is excessive. Peaceful protest is a democratic right. I hope the Bahraini government will rescind this measure as quickly as possible. I also call on protesters to desist from violent protest. Violent acts should be condemned publicly by prominent members in society."

Shias comprise about 70% of Bahrain's 525,000 citizens, who claim they face systematic discrimination and gerrymandering of constituency boundaries.

The monarchy has made a series of concessions, including giving more powers to the elected parliament, but opposition groups say the reforms do little to loosen the ruling family's hold on power. More than 50 people have been killed in Bahrain's unrest since February 2011.

How do you win an MLS Cup? Well, first you have to make the playoffs. This is one of those feats that seems easy when you look at the raw numbers – 19 teams set off with hope in their hearts in March and come the end of October, there are 10 left when the playoffs start.

These are hardly daunting odds – yet just as the English Championship is a horrible league to get out of when you find yourself in it, the parity of standards structurally enforced by MLS mean that making the play-offs, and nursing a team along to peak in time for them, is an art in itself. Just ask the DC United team who won the Supporters Shield in 2007 then missed the next four playoffs before their 2012 return. Just ask Dominic Kinnear, whose Houston Dynamo went from almost last in the West in 2010 to edge into the 2011 playoffs and make a run to the final, or the Colorado Rapids side who won the whole thing in 2010 from the unpromising platform of fifth in the West.

Clearly, just making the playoffs is not enough – you also need momentum. Those Colorado and Houston sides had it, so who has it this year?

On results, if not form, you could do worse than an outside look at DC United, who have ground their way back from Dwayne De Rosario's season-ending injury to finish second in the East, or of course San Jose Earthquakes, who were Supporters Shield winners having led from the front for most of the year and who have goalscorer Chris Wondolowski concluding a career year on top form. Sporting Kansas City won an Open Cup this year and Peter Vermes and the No1 Eastern seeds feel they know how to win now.

Some other teams, with varying degrees of supporting evidence, may feel that it's just their turn – step forward the Seattle Sounders and New York Red Bulls. And of course there are the defending champions, LA Galaxy, who have a difficult fourth-placed Western seeding to negotiate but put themselves in that position with a fine second half of the season.

.

So just who can win MLS Cup? Here we consider the entrants team by team and ask who the key players will be.

Tomorrow we'll have our usual fan previews for the wild-card games. And be sure to join us for live coverage of all the playoff games, starting with the first wild-card match on Wednesday night, as Chicago Fire take on Houston Dynamo. Our coverage starts around 8.30pm.

MLS Cup 2012 playoffs guide

Overall seedings shown in brackets. When the finalists are determined, the highest-ranking seed will host the match.

Wild-card games are one-off games played at the higher-seeded team's stadium. Conference semi-finals and finals are played over a home-and-road series. In the event of an aggregate tie the second game, played at the higher seed's stadium, will go to extra time and penalties if necessary.

Eastern Conference

Wild card (single game): Chicago Fire v Houston Dynamo

Semi-final (two legs): Sporting Kansas City v Chicago or Houston; DC United v New York Red Bulls

1. Sporting Kansas City (2)

Will play either Chicago Fire or Houston Dynamo in the Eastern Conference semi-final. First leg is on Saturday afternoon.

For seven games this season it looked as if Sporting KC were going to run away with the Eastern conference, as they made a perfect start. Then a Chance Myers own-goal undid them at Portland and they began to look vulnerable. But when I spoke to Peter Vermes last month, he emphasized that he had built this team around individuals who would "bend but not break", and as the season unfolded so it proved. Sporting had setbacks to deal with but remained fundamentally resilient in the face of the surging and waning form of those around them in the East.

An Open Cup win got them started on the process of "painting the wall" at their new stadium and gave the team belief, but Vermes said that the big game that made this side was not that win so much as last season's Eastern Conference final defeat by Houston.

Sporting will be tough for any opponent – they press and harry from the front, with Kei Kamara and Graham Zusi pressing and swapping sides to give defenders nightmares, and Roger Espinoza dominating midfield. When they impose themselves they are especially adept at bringing the fullbacks Chance Myers and Seth Sinovic forward and flooding the midfield to overwhelm teams, while Jimmy Nielsen had another rock-solid season in goal. If CJ Sapong can get among the goals consistently, they'll take some stopping.

Key man: When Sporting have failed to impose themselves early and opponents have pushed them back, Jimmy Nielsen has kept his team in games singlehandedly. Aurélien Colin's value at the heart of defense is very apparent when he's not there. Graham Zusi's dead balls are very dangerous, and he's taken another leap in his progress this year. But Kei Kamara is unplayable on his day, and it will be great to see him grace the playoffs.

2. DC United (3)

Will play New York Red Bulls in Eastern Conference semi-final. First leg is in New York on Saturday night.

Two seasons ago, DC finished rock bottom of the East. Last season they missed out on the playoffs with a heartbreaking falter on the run-in. So when Dwayne De Rosario, team talisman and creative force, went down with a season-ending injury a few weeks ago, everyone prepared to avert their eyes from the sight of one of the first great MLS teams falling apart, as per recent history. Instead, Ben Olsen's team seemed to relish the task that faced them and in the spirit of their coach got back to basics. It was rather too basic for some purists' tastes but whether winning ugly or not, DC tightened their defense and found a way to get the job done, including last weekend in Chicago when they came from behind to earn the draw that relegated their hosts to the wild-card game.

DC's reward is a semi-final against rivals New York, which if previous encounters this season are anything to go by will mean goals. The teams have shared 14 in their three encounters, though the run that has carried DC into the third overall seeding was not built on free-scoring exploits, so it will be interesting to see if United stick or twist. Regardless, it's possible we'll have a treat of a semi-final series that either side will then struggle to match in the following round.

Key Player: Bill Hamid. It would probably have been DeRo and Chris Pontius will be key in the games against New York, since he loves scoring against them; it might also be worth keeping a sly eye out for the supersub Lewis Neal. But Hamid's goalkeeping kept his side in the game against Chicago and if his side are to go deep in the playoffs there's going to be at least one tight game in which DC will need him to come up big.

3. New York Red Bulls (4)


Will play DC United in Eastern Conference semi-final. First leg is in New York on Saturday night.

Points-wise, this was New York Red Bulls' best year, exceeding their 2010 Eastern conference-winning total by six. Kenny Cooper's 18 goals were just one shy of Juan Pablo Angel's single-season club record, while Thierry Henry had 15 goals and rather more tellingly, 12 assists – when the Red Bulls are clicking offensively, everything goes through the Frenchman.

When they're clicking defensively – an aim that has been the subject of much alchemical speculation by the coaching staff this year – Dax McCarty has been somewhere in the mix. As a defensive midfielder McCarty was a revelation earlier in the season – so much so that even with the arrival of Tim Cahill and the returns of Teemu Tainio and Rafa Marquez, a place had to be found for their less illustrious colleague. At the moment it's on the wing, which doesn't necessarily play to New York's strengths or address their big weakness – speed. With Dane Richards gone to Vancouver and his putative replacement, Lloyd Sam, out for the season, on a bad day New York look ponderous.

On a good day, though, they have more expensively-assembled skill in their squad than most teams and have been able to pass their way to fourth-place overall. What Hans Backe needs to do is make those good days appear against the league's better sides more consistently. Backe is supposedly living on borrowed time as coach since the departure of sporting director Eric Soler a few weeks ago, though in truth the clock has been ticking throughout his third year in charge, if not since his arrival. When we met in pre-season, Backe said of the upcoming year: "It's time to win a trophy." New York's fans and owners would agree.

Key Player: It would be perverse to go for anyone other than Thierry Henry. When he's on form, New York score goals and the side is built around maximizing his contribution. They also may need Kenny Cooper to keep scoring, Tim Cahill to turn finding-his-feet performances into dominant ones and Rafa Marquez to continue with the composed if not speedy performances he's been turning in at the heart of defense recently. (Not getting sent off for instigating a mass brawl in this year's semi-final would also help.) But Henry is the key.

4. Chicago Fire (6)

Will host Houston Dynamo in a wild-card game on Wednesday night. Winners will face Sporting Kansas City in the Eastern Conference semi-final, with the first leg on Saturday afternoon.

If this Eastern season were a 1500m race, Houston would be the side that kicked for home too early on the back straight, while Chicago would be the side that glided past them with 200m to go, only to find, in a panic, that the afterburners weren't there in the home stretch.

As summer turned to fall, the Fire roared into contention in the East, after a mid-season overhaul by Frank Klopas that brought back home-town hero Chris Rolfe, introduced Alex and Macdonald and, the disappointing Fernandez aside, saw his attack actually make net gains after Marco Pappa's departure. Then with the end and possibly even an Eastern top seeding in sight, the Fire began to sputter – the nadir being a loss to a New England side long finished as a competitive concern. A home draw with DC on the last day allowed New York to edge the Fire out of the semi-final places.

Despite missing out on a "medal" position, Chicago can still knock the other contenders out and over two legs they can cause anyone problems. They've beaten New York home and away and Sporting Kansas City too have been exposed to what this Fire team can do when countering at speed.

First, there's the small matter of a Halloween wild-card game against a well-rested Houston side, who should have all the tools to keep the game close, contest the midfield and ask a lot of questions. It's a game in which the Fire can ill-afford to fall behind, as they've done a little too often recently.

Key Player: When Chris Rolfe found his feet on his return to the club, he really demonstrated what they'd been missing. Patrick Nyarko and Dominick Oduro's raw speed had plundered goals early in the season, but the Fire sometimes lacked the bite and guile Rolfe brings in the final third. His game had dropped off a little recently, but if he finds his form he could be key. Also keep an eye on Arne Friedrich and Austin Berry at the back. The latter has deservedly emerged as rookie of the year frontrunner while the veteran Friedrich gave a master class in shutting down Thierry Henry as Chicago took the points in New York. With Chicago stumbling, the German's composure will be vital.

5. Houston Dynamo (9)

Will travel to Chicago Fire in a one-off wild-card game on Wednesday night. Winner will face Sporting Kansas City in the Eastern Conference semi-final, with the first leg taking place on Saturday afternoon.

In 2010, New York opened a new stadium and rode their home form to top the Eastern conference. In 2011 Sporting Kansas City did the same. In 2012 Houston opened their new stadium and all the omens were there for a repeat. Just as Sporting had done the previous season, the Dynamo front-loaded their schedule with road trips then entered their new home knowing that not only would they play the balance of their remaining games at home, but would do so largely against eastern opposition.

That was coupled with Dominic Kinnear's overhaul of the side from a 4-4-2 outfit dependent on the talented but young Will Bruin and the effective but aging Brian Ching into a technically efficient 4-3-3 built around the inventiveness of Boniek Garcia and the heart of the team, Brad Davis. The system gelled quickly as Houston went on a run at the end of summer, only to falter in the fall. They finished the regular season glad to see Columbus Crew's resurgence fall just short.

Now they play Chicago ifor the honor of facing Sporting KC. On the negative side the game is at Toyota Park, so Houston must travel – no easy prospect in a week of national travel disruption. On the plus side, they're well rested. New York's win at Philadelphia on the final Saturday meant Houston had nothing to play for at Colorado, so Kinnear rested several starters. He knows a thing or two about preparing a side to time their run for the play-offs, does Kinnear – can he work his magic again this year?

Key player: Brad Davis is the obvious choice. When he limped out of last year's Eastern Conference final, Houston's MLS Cup hopes went with him. The team is still shaped round the captain and midfielder. The experience of Ricardo Clark and Brian Ching could be crucial too. But Macoumba Kandji is also key, in that he may be the most infuriatingly talented player in a Houston shirt. He can and does go on slaloming runs to score wonderful goals, but more often will go past three defenders at speed before shooting wide or failing to make the simple pass. The 4-3-3 should be made for Kandji and it has offered glimpses of what he can do, but it also comes with a caveat that Kandji sometimes ignores – to make it work you need your front three to defend too. If Kinnear could get the best out of a more disciplined Kandji he could yet play more than a cameo in these playoffs.

Western Conference

Wild card (single game): LA Galaxy vs Vancouver Whitecaps

Semi-final (two legs): San Jose Earthquakes v LA or Vancouver; Real Salt Lake v Seattle Sounders

1. San Jose Earthquakes (1)


Will play LA Galaxy or Vancouver Whitecaps in Western Conference semi-finals, starting Sunday night

The Earthquakes have been the story of the season. Most of the attention is rightly on the record-equalling 27 goals of Chris Wondolowski, ably backed by the "Bash Brothers" duo of Steven Lenhart and Alan Gordon – enjoying their own career years and filling the very few minor slumps in Wondolowski's goalscoring to take the attacking trio's regular-season goals total to a truly impressive 50.

But the supply lines for the attack have been eye-catching too – Simon Dawkins has been consistently dangerous from midfield and Marvin Chavez has chipped in with 13 assists from the flanks. And looking down the San Jose roster, you see names (Rafael Baca, Steven Beitashour, Justin Morrow) who have had great years in a team exceeding the sum of their parts.

San Jose play every game like it's a cup tie. They've scored more stoppage-time goals than any other team this year – more than a quarter of their games have featured game-changing overtime goals. One more time: "Goonies never say die..."

Key player: Who else? Chris Wondolowski. Twenty-seven goals, the focal point of the Earthquakes attack – coming into the playoffs, Wondo has scored five in the last three games.

2. Real Salt Lake (5)

Will play Seattle Sounders in Western Conference semi-finals, starting Friday night in Seattle

For a team that supposedly can't score, is breaking up and is out of form, Real Salt Lake didn't do badly to finish second in the West this year. Playing under perhaps the best young coach in the league, Jason Kreis, RSL started strongly and then pushed through an indifferent summer that included a 5-0 humbling in San Jose, while trying to keep a creaking roster together for one more Concacaf Champions League campaign.

That ended in disappointment last week, of course, and it remains to be seen just what that will have done to RSL's confidence – but for all the questions posed around this team this year, and their drops in form and goalscoring, Kreis has made the 2009 champions find ways to be competitive – they became the first side to beat LA Galaxy at home twice in one season, took all the points at Seattle and while Alvaro Saborio and Fabian Espindola have been somewhat intermittent in terms of goalscoring consistency, on their day they know how to unlock any defense.

First up is a repeat of RSL's epic to-and-fro 2011 semi-final against Seattle. After a 3-0 victory at the Rio Tinto, RSL survived a late Seattle surge in a 2-0 loss in the return, a game memorable for Tony Beltran's wonderful headed clearance. Kreis has stuck to his principles and has been blooding young players this year. There's no doubt that he has a less experienced pool going into this series than he did in 2011, but this time RSL have the nominal advantage of playing the second leg at home... not that it did Seattle much good last year.

Key Player: It's hard to look past Alvaro Saborio's 17 goals, but if Salt Lake are to progress they need the extra dimension of an in-form Javier Morales to pull some creative strings in the midfield.

3. Seattle Sounders (7)

Will play Real Salt Lake in Western Conference semi-final, starting Friday night in Seattle

It seems like every year the Sounders come into the MLS playoffs tipped to win it all, and every year they fall short. Will it be different this year? Well, first Santos in the CCL quarter finals and then Sporting KC in the Sounders' beloved Open Cup have narrowed the prospects for a glittering season down to MLS Cup or bust, so Seattle have an incentive to correct the mistakes of the past.

Key to that will be an emphatic performance in Friday's first leg semi-final game against Real Salt Lake – hopefully with Eddie Johnson on the field. The club-record 14-goal man pulled up feeling his hamstring in the final game of the regular season, in LA, and came off the field, supposedly as a precaution. Johnson is a big part of Seattle's offensive armory, alongside perennial favorite Fredy Montero. Behind them, the summer arrival of Christian Tiffert has firmed up the supply lines to the strikers and Mauro Rosales and the returning Steve Zakuani give a multi-dimensional nature to the attack. The question is whether all these moving parts can combine to negotiate their way through the playoffs against more integrated teams.

Key Player: Michael Gspurning. Yes the strikers are vital, but the defense may be the key for the Sounders. Replacing Kasey Keller in goal was always going to be a huge ask, but Gspurning has truly looked the part and it's no coincidence that Seattle's worst spell of the year coincided with his absence through injury. If Gspurning and the hard tackling of Osvaldo Alonso can give Seattle a strong defensive platform, the Sounders will fancy their chances of getting the goals they need to progress.

4. Los Angeles Galaxy (8)


Will host Vancouver Whitecaps in a one off wild-card game on Thursday night; winner will play San Jose in the Western Conference semi-final

It has been a season of two halves for the MLS Cup holders, who at one point looked like very long shots to get the chance to defend their title, after an awful start. The sight of New England Revolution hitting three in an early season game at the former Home Depot Center fortress told you everything you needed to know about how the Galaxy were coping without the injured Omar Gonzalez at the heart of defense. More troubling was the fact that the big names – Landon Donovan, Robbie Keane, David Beckhams – looked anonymous, perhaps preoccupied with thoughts of looming international tournaments.

It was in the wake of those tournaments, and the return of Gonzalez to stabilize the defense, that the Galaxy snapped back into form. Keane returned from a disappointing Euro 2012 with renewed focus, while Beckham and Donovan missed the Olympics entirely (other than a speedboat cameo for the former) and threw themselves into their club side's cause. Most importantly, senior figures in the locker room re-instituted a culture of accountability and results began to improve dramatically, even before the arrival of the smart Swedish international Christian Wilhelmsson to give the champions some creativity out wide. The Galaxy may be peaking at the right time.

Key Player: It's tempting to say Gonzalez, because of the night-and-day effect of him being in or out of the side, but let's take that as a given. Keane has found his scoring touch and his movement makes a lot of space for smart players around him. The key though is the form (and perhaps mood) of Landon Donovan. He played a full 90 minutes on his return from injury at the weekend, but looked way short of match condition. Nonetheless he showed flashes of the invention, vision and at moments drive that will be a key part of a successful LA cup defense.

5. Vancouver Whitecaps (10)

Will visit LA Galaxy in a one-off wild-card game on Thursday night; winner will play San Jose in the Western Conference semi-final

As we said, if you want to win MLS Cup you first have to make the playoffs. Vancouver did that – just. Martin Rennie arrived after an underwhelming debut MLS season for the Whitecaps and overhauled his side in the offseason to become many peoples' outside tip for MLS Cup. The team started solidly, if perhaps a little stolidly – building off a firm defense and home form to stay in touch with the leaders.

Whether Rennie tried to rush his revolution, or sides figured out the new-look Whitecaps, Vancouver seemed to lose their way as the season went on, as the signings they brought in to give them more attacking sophistication rather unbalanced the side. They did combine for a late-season four-goal salvo against Chivas USA, which combined with the same opponent's subsequent tie with FC Dallas saw Vancouver over the line.

The Whitecaps now face a wild-card trip to a Galaxy team that have had their measure since Vancouver entered the league, but if – and it's a big if – they can negotiate that, they will find themselves playing San Jose as one of the few sides who've consistently troubled the Earthquakes this year. That has been at least in part because they are unfazed by the physical style of a team like the Earthquakes. The Whitecaps have beaten the Supporters Shield winners twice this year and while they will go to LA hoping regular-season form is no indicator of playoff outcomes, should they prevail at the Home Depot Center you'd forgive their fans for welcoming San Jose thinking, "Maybe, just maybe..."

Key Player: Camilo Sanvezzo. The Whitecaps will need Jay DeMerit on form to keep the Galaxy attack out. They'll need the designated players, Barry Robson and Kenny Miller, to come good and demonstrate that they truly represent the next stage of the team's evolution – though if the stories coming out of Vancouver are any indication, they may be doing so from the bench. They may even need Dane Richards or rookie MVP candidate Darren Mattocks to perform speedy wonders off the bench. But the main thing the Whitecaps need is for an in form Camilo to make creative things happen for the offense and keep himself out of trouble while doing so.

Steve Diamond found himself in an awkward position for a chief executive at Sale's Carrington training base on Tuesday afternoon – explaining why, a few months after recommending that Bryan Redpath should be appointed director of rugby on a four-year contract reported to be worth a seven-figure sum, he had decided to reclaim the job for himself and demote the Scotsman.

However Diamond has had plenty of practice. Since returning to Sale, for whom he was a tough and uncompromising hooker then coach, as executive director of sport in February 2011, the 44-year-old has twice before felt obliged to revert to coaching after deciding that his replacements were not up to the job.

Tony Hanks, a New Zealander who previously worked at Wasps, was the first to fall short of Diamond's expectations in March, when he was sacked as head coach after less than eight months in charge, and only one month after signing a contract extension. Diamond resumed control for the rest of the season but then moved for Redpath, the former Scotland scrum-half who just happened to have requested a release from his contract with Gloucester.

That allowed Diamond to concentrate once more on the commercial side of the club ahead of their move from Stockport to the City of Salford Stadium this season. But then, only four matches into this season after Sale had suffered a fourth consecutive defeat at home to London Welsh, he deemed himself the man to sort out the faltering Sharks forwards after sacking Steve Scott, the former Scotland international who had been an appointment of a previous regime.

So Diamond has been combining the positions of chief executive and forwards coach for the past month, a period during which the situation at Sale became even more complicated as the famously abrasive former All Blacks coach John Mitchell was invited back to the club as a consultant - "to give a helicopter view", Diamond explained. Less than two weeks ago, Redpath said he had been reassured by Diamond that despite Mitchell's arrival his role as director of rugby "wouldn't change in any way". He said he would have "no issues" working alongside Mitchell, and that "our egos have to be put to one side".

Within days, Mitchell told journalists who followed Sale to Montpellier for a Heineken Cup defeat "teams can only have one leader". The assumption was that leader would be him. But now Diamond insists he will be in charge for the rest of the season. Mitchell will remain as a consultant until next spring at least, but he flew back to South Africa on Tuesday morning to "finish some details", according to Diamond – a reference to the acrimonious legal battle that followed his suspension by the Golden Lions in June after complaints from the players about his management style.

He is not expected back before Friday night's home game against London Irish, a distinctly winnable fixture for Sale in which victory has now become imperative. But Diamond said Redpath could yet be involved in preparing the team for that match, having been offered a new coaching role.

"We've asked Bryan just to take a little bit of time out, a couple of days off to reconsider what we are doing and how we restructure our rugby department," Diamond explained.

"We want him to be involved moving forward. He is contracted for a long time after making a big move from Gloucester. We just need to get the balance of that right, and it clearly isn't right, judging by our results.

"I know Bryan Redpath very well personally and through the job, and the decision to have a rethink about the coaching staff hasn't been done overnight. We've been talking about it a few weeks now because of results. Most people would get fired if I'm honest after seven or eight losses. That hasn't been the case here. What we're trying to do is put other plans in place."

Redpath, who has yet to make any public comment, has been asked to give Sale an answer by Wednesday morning. "All the talks are very positive at the moment," Diamond added. "I certainly want him involved and John Mitchell thinks he does a good job."

But it will be Diamond who leads the battle to avoid relegation from the Premiership, which he admits "would be a disaster".

"What we need is a bit of stability," he added with a straight face, after instigating this third major change in the past nine months. "It needs a steady hand on the ship. That's why I find myself coming back to the coaching. Our team has got stronger on paper over the summer, we just need to get them playing together better. We won't suffer the indignity of not winning games like we have been – we've got to make changes. I don't know what people expected me to do. The examples of what happened to Newcastle, to Northampton, to Harlequins in previous years are clear if you leave it too late.

"As chief executive I've got to take full responsibility, and what you do in these positions is bring people in who are capable, with a proven track record of doing a good job. Sometimes it doesn't work and unfortunately it hasn't. We've created a non-blame culture. You can point fingers wherever you want, but the players are very tight and ultimately working through it. We want to be a hard-working, abrasive side, and we've started to show a bit of that of late. I'm sure that will show again on Friday night."
