The Department for Education (DfE) in association with care leavers, charities and local authorities has this week launched a council charter for care leavers. The charter is based on six principles of support: identity and aspiration, listening to care leavers' views, support when needed, information, finding care leavers a home and working together.

As a care leaver, I support the pledge to stand by young people as they adjust to independence. However, an opportunity has been missed to campaign for our most at risk youth to receive the security they deserve. In society, adolescence has become extended, with parental support continuing much longer than in the past. But our care system forces too many young people into adulthood prematurely.

I was in care, permanently excluded from education at 14, and written off by the care system. My journey has been long and far from smooth, but, now aged 36 and completing my PhD, I am a clear example of why care leaver support must be extended. Policymakers fail to "think stage not age" when deciding when a care leaver no longer needs support. The whole system is obsessed with outcomes at 16 or 19.

I have spent four years reviewing what is known about leaving care and, carrying out empirical research across England, I have met amazing care leavers, some excelling in higher education and apprenticeships, as well as inspirational single parents. But I have also met many who are homeless, unemployed, stuck in the criminal justice system and at risk of exploitation. Will the charter help them? It promises "to prepare you for your move into independent living only when you are ready". For many care leavers this would mean staying in care beyond 18, 21 or even 25. But how many local authorities will commit to this when they cannot afford those care leavers they already have? As budgets are cut, and the number of children coming into care rises, the number of care leavers is increasing by around 5% a year.

There are three main concerns about the charter: the only signatory is the DfE, the corporate parent; most of what is pledged is already covered in legislation and should be standard practice; and where does a care leaver go if they feel they are not being treated as the charter requires? There is no ombudsman for looked-after children.

I hoped the charter would make some tangible promises such as "We will not let you become homeless", "We will financially support those who choose alternative education routes in the same way as those who go to university", but it falls short.

The then Labour health secretary Frank Dobson offered the most comprehensive, yet succinct, charter in 1998, stating: "Your council has a legal and moral duty to provide the kind of loyal support any good parents would their own children." Many local authorities and professionals aspire to this. But good parenting for care leavers means continued support by their corporate parents and the charter fails to guarantee this.

• Mark Kerr is a researcher from the Outcomes of Care study funded by the Economic and Social Research Council at the University of Kent

• If you are a care leaver (of any age) or you work with care leavers, you can participate in the Outcomes of Care research at the University of Kent at outcomesofcare.com

One week ago I attended a conference at Olympia called Place West London, where politicians, regeneration sages and the property trade gathered to talk money, land and homes. I first listened to Councillor Andrew Johnson, Hammersmith and Fulham (H&F) council's cabinet member for housing, who addressed the implications for local authorities of new powers and responsibilities devolved to them.

He said that for the first time, "we have meaningful control of our housing assets," which meant taking, "meaningful, long term financial decisions." A 30-year business plan was required, allowing for future investment. There was "more local political accountability," which he described as "a mixed blessing at times." He was disappointed that, "Local authorities do not have the freedom to manage housing stock," to the same degree as housing associations have. "Crucially, as far as I'm concerned," he said, "We are still unable to set market rates or to share equity in council house property."

Johnson's brief peroration was directly about the borough he was representing: "Hammersmith and Fulham is a borough of opportunity," he said, repeating a core slogan of the Conservative administration. "We are an ambitious borough, but we are also a borough that sees a failure in the current housing market within London." He said that H&F has the fourth highest property property prices in the UK, 34% social housing and only 3% of housing in the "intermediate" category - the more expensive end of the "affordable" range, where aspiring home owners look to get a toe hold on the property ladder. This dearth of intermediate homes was Johnson's evidence for the market failure he identified and wished to correct. "Hammersmith and Fulham is determined to look to build for the middle market," he said.

This was not a new statement of intent. It has been a public cry of H&F ever since the Conservatives won control of the borough under Stephen Greenhalgh, now Boris Johnson's policing office chief, in 2006. When famously declaring the borough open for business" in September 2007, Greenhalgh told a summit of property developers that his administration wanted to "build a housing ladder of opportunity for all." Three months earlier H&F's preferred "core strategy" options document (pdf) included addressing "the demand for housing and the lack of housing for households with incomes of between about £19,000 and £60,000." The document continued:

The council will seek 40% affordable housing in new developments. Of the affordable housing, 10-15% will be social rented housing and 25-30% intermediate housing. The council will also expect a proportion of the market housing to be low cost market housing and affordable to households on moderate incomes.

After Johnson's session was complete I moved rooms to listen to an update on the Earls Court project, one of London's largest redevelopment schemes and a subject of great interest to me as it seems to crystalise key regeneration issues of this "localist" age. Most of the land in question falls within H&F's borders. Stephen Greenhalgh remains a keen supporter of the project, describing it to the Guardian earlier this year as "the best deal in the history of redevelopment in London."

The update was provided by Richard Powell, who is director of planning and development of EC Properties, the wholly-owned subsidiary of H&F's developer partner Capco that is responsible for the Earls Court project.

Before Powell addressed a gathering of maybe 30 people, I asked him a couple of questions. He was good enough to answer them on the record. Was he confident that the Earls Court project would actually go ahead in the end? "Yes," he replied. I pointed out that critics variously say that it's too big and complicated, that Capco won't be able to raise the money it needs and that the pending corruption trial of two members of the Kwok family from Hong Kong, one of whose property businesses has joined forces with Capco to fund the development of a part of the project area, does not bode well. Wasn't it all getting rather messy?

Powell said he thought such a concern was valid - there are, for example, a lot of different interested parties, including Transport for London, Kensington and Chelsea and the Greater London Authority - and acknowledged that the Earls Court project is "a grand plan." But he pointed out that Capco and EC had been setting out their stall for months and years and, "We are just very keen to deliver on our promises."

I asked Powell about the allegations that a so-called "VIP list" or "Early Movers List" has been compiled of residents of the Gibbs Green and West Kensington estates who've been promised preferential treatment in the allocation of replacement homes for their existing ones, which are threatened with demolition as part of the Earls Court project, in return for expressing support for the project.

The council has commissioned an investigation into these allegations following the delivery of a dossier to the police, which claims to contain evidence that council officers were involved in making such promises and argues that, if so, this would be illegal. I've heard an assortment of stories of promises of one type of another of new homes being made to residents by people favouring the project. Did Powell think any of them were true? He said that in view of the police receiving the dossier and the council's investigation it wouldn't be appropriate to comment.

I also asked him about responses to the council's consultation of residents who'd be affected by the project, primarily those of the occupants of the 760 homes that the West Kensington and Gibbs Green estates comprise. Powell said that Capco had responded to an earlier consultation by trying to, "get into the community and make sure people really understood what was happening."

He also pointed out that responses to the consultation I was referring to, which was about the council's plan to sell the land the estates stand on to Capco, had been "broadly supportive" from residents in the wider area, though he acknowledged that from the estates themselves - where the response rate was very high, compared with what I pointed out was a very low one among residents in the surrounding area - "the numbers were the other way round." He said he'd looked at the feedback earlier in the year. "It was interesting," he said, but added that, "ultimately, that's the council's decision - it wasn't our decision to include the estates in the plans."

Powell then delivered his update, in which he described the Earls Court project as, "Trying to deliver what's great about London," in a part of the city that had been by-passed by previous phases of development. He made light of a forthcoming judicial review of a key planning document relating to the scheme, saying in effect that such things were to be expected. He envisaged a new "district of squares," preferring the term to "villages." The guiding mantra, he said, is "London-plus." And he reprised the project's main selling points of job creation, imaginative place-making, the provision of green space, a new high street, exterior improvements to Underground stations and the building of 7,500 new homes in all.

A key question for me is the amount of these 7,500 homes that will be genuinely affordable to the very "middle market" people Andrew Johnson had said during the previous hour that his borough is determined to help; the same people, in fact, that Boris Johnson spoke up for earlier this month in his Telegraph column. Powell relayed to his audience that 1,500 of the 7,500 will be categorised "affordable," with 760 of these being the replacement homes promised to residents of West Kensington and Gibbs Green, leaving "an additional" figure of 740, all in the "intermediate" affordable category.

I put it to Powell that this was a very low percentage - about 11% once you stripped out the 760 replacements, which is far from what has H&F publicly aspired to. He replied that hitting affordable targets of up to 50% was proving difficult all over London, and that the "joint financial model" on which the Earls Court project is based, "went through an independent test by the Valuation Office, which he said was "pretty similar to most other projects," and that the affordable housing element had emerged from this.

The wider context was the scheme's overall viability. In other words, as Powell put it, "Making sure this scheme can happen. These sorts of projects, [when they] are fairly dogmatic about policy, often never get off the ground. The one thing that I'm very very keen on, is that this bloody thing happens and that we don't just talk about it as some interesting design exercise. So from the viability point of view I think we now are on the right side of the line to give ourselves a fighting chance."

I asked if the inclusion of the two estates in the development area had, perhaps, made things more difficult for EC Properties/Capco. I had in mind that, as Powell had earlier reminded me, it was H&F that had wanted them included, and also that opposition among their residents was so strong.

Powell, replied: "I think - and I guess I would wouldn't I? - that, actually, the inclusion of all of this land in a comprehensive development is a good solution, and it will enhance the lives of all of the neighbourhoods that live in the broader area. I think they will all be able to benefit through the employment and training budgets, and everything that can flow from this. But I fully accept that living on the estates at the moment there is a level of uncertainty - hang on a second, what is going on here and what's going to happen? [But] we have done a pretty unprecedented level of planning consultation...I do think, though, that overall the benefits of the system justify the inclusion of this whole area - this phased development over time."

Finally, I pressed him further on the opposition of the two estates' residents. Was there a concern that Capco and EC Properties would be seen as the archetypal, big, nasty property developer trampling over the little people? Could such a perception be damaging?

In his reply Powell said that, "We want to see what's best for London, what's best for the borough, and what's best for the residents of the estates," and that, "Hammersmith and Fulham are quite clear that on the basis of all their information and all the other benefits which can flow from very substantial investment in this part of town, that it is worth moving forward on that basis."

He stressed that, "From our point of view, we just want to be shoulder to shoulder with Hammersmith and Fulham. We want to make sure there is no misalignment of interests, and we're able to move forward together. As I say, I think the overall benefits of the scheme, in the long term, are worthwhile, and we'll be pursuing it with vigour."

I was later told that that by the end of Powell's talk, Andrew Johnson had joined the gathering, sitting near the back of the room. Had I known, I might have asked him about the low percentage of homes envisaged by the Earls Court project that might be affordable to those struggling middle market Londoners for whom he and Mayor Johnson have expressed concern, and if he truly believes that no more could have been provided.

I might also have put it to him that apart from Capco and Tory politicians such as himself and the London mayor, very few people are speaking up for the Earls Court project as it stands. And, who knows, maybe even some of them are having doubts.

In 2004, Observer Sports Monthly published its list of the "50 sporting things you must do before you die". At number one was attending a "superclásico", the passionate encounter between Argentina's bitter rivals Boca Juniors and River Plate.

The standard of the Argentinian league was declining even then – it has got a lot worse since – but the superclásico remains special. Sunday's was ninth against fifth between two teams who, in all honesty, aren't very good and yet el Monumental was packed, seething with noise and colour and passion.

Argentinian football often gives the impression that the league is a tiresome irrelevance. There may be 190 games in each half-season but only one really matters. This, presumably, is why it persists with the ludicrous, short-season structure that produces two champions each season – and, as of this season, a superchampion, the winner of a play-off between the winners of each half of the season (a lengthy review process ended up doing nothing but adding the play-off and changing the names of each half of the season from apertura and clausura to inicial and final).

That's why River's relegation in June 2011 came as such a blow. It wasn't just that the promedio system, that sees relegation calculated on a coefficient determined over three years and was supposed to ensure one of the grandees never went down, had been outwitted (Independiente and San Lorenzo could easily follow River this season); it was that there would be no superclásicos for at least a year.

River were – not entirely convincingly – promoted at the first attempt, but that still meant an unprecedented, 17-month gap between superclásicos.

The build-up to Sunday's game felt like the unleashing of an awful lot of pent-up emotion. In terms of atmosphere, it didn't disappoint. For half an hour before kick-off, the stadium rang with noise. It was awash with red-and-white (and, in a small section, blue-and-yellow) balloons and thundersticks and ticker-tape. It's usual to criticise running tracks at stadiums, saying they kill atmosphere; at el Monumental, the track and the moat – quite aside from being necessary as a security measure – serve to distance the pitch from the stands, not just physically but metaphorically, enhancing the sense of theatre, of the game as something remote and otherworldly.

El Monumental also gives a wonderful sense of stepping back in time.

Perhaps it's the ticker-tape, perhaps the aesthetic, perhaps the vague sense of dilapidation, but it does feel as though you could come back a week later and see not Leandro Somoza against Ezequiel Cirigliano, but Johan Neeskens against Mario Kempes. It presumably has been painted since the 1978 World Cup final, but it does a good job of hiding it.

And it's the fans, of course, who make it. It's said 70% of Argentina support either Boca or River, and those who go to the stadium are devoutly noisy. Chanting isn't restricted to those in their teens and twenties — as it tended to be even in the seventies and eighties in Britain. It's not unusual to see men in their sixties clambering on railings to find a better spot to taunt their rivals. At half-time, River fans floated an enormous inflatable pig in a Boca shirt in front of the away fans – a reference to the "porqueros" (pigs) insult supposedly derived from the smell of the riverfront home of Boca's Bombonera stadium. Boca fans responded by alternately raising right then left hands to suggest River, after their one season in National B are somehow a yoyo club. Some Boca fans had even come dressed as ghosts to remind River they'll always be haunted by that relegation.

The flip side of the colour and the passion is the violence. When I arrived at the ground about two-and-a-half hours before kick-off, the atmosphere was calm, if tense. Knots of police, armed with batons around five feet long and two or three inches in diameter clustered on street corners and there were occasional volleys of what you hoped were firecrackers, but essentially the mood seemed of apprehensive good humour.

I'd come down Figueroa Alcorta and it seems I was lucky. Others who approached on Libertador, which runs parallel but in the opposite direction, reported seeing eight buses that had carried Boca fans with their windows smashed. Elsewhere fans threw stones at police while there were scuffles in the streets after the game that left 25 people injured, an 18-year-old seriously so.

But the worst incident came shortly after River had gone 2-0 up, when a section of the Boca fans, high in the upper tier of the stand behind the goal in which Rodrigo Mora had scored, turned their frustrations on stewards. A few were flung down the stairs in the stands and kicked and punched as they lay stricken. At least one appeared to have been beaten into unconsciousness. Television pictures, which eye-witness accounts suggested missed the worst of the violence, seemed to show other fans intervening. Fortunately for the stewards, who were employed by a private security company, Boca were soon awarded a penalty. With Santiago Silva providing a distraction by collapsing under minimal contact from Germán Pezzella, Lautaro Acosta was tripped by Leandro González Pirez. Silva converted with a powerful strike.

That goal unexpectedly awakened a game that had seemed settled. River, having gone ahead after 90 seconds when Leandro Ponzio's free-kick eluded Agustín Orión, looked in control – if more because of Boca's shortcomings than their own prowess. Boca had gone four games without a win before the superclásico and it was easy to see why.

With a bona fide playmaker to do their conjuring for them, perhaps the industrious but unimaginative front pairing of Silva and Lucas Viatri could work. With Juan Román Riquelme in stasis – not formally retired and still on Boca's books but refusing to play, leading to hints he may return if, as expected, Julio César Falcioni's contract as coach is not renewed and he is replaced by Carlos Bianchi at the end of the year – Boca are desperately short of flair and quality. Christian Chávez disappointed again, Walter Erviti looks better playing a little deeper and making late runs and Leandro Paredes, who has been linked with Arsenal but looks more likely to move to Juventus, is 18 and inconsistent.

With Orión, confidence shot, flapping despairingly at every cross, it seemed only a matter of time before River extended their lead, even if they weren't exactly applying sustained pressure. Sure enough, the second goal arrived after 71 minutes, Rodrigo Mora rounding Orión and finishing smartly from a narrow angle after a deliciously weighted through-ball from Carlos Sánchez.

Even at 2-1 it didn't seem as though River were under much pressure.

Acosta's liveliness had given Boca a threat they hadn't had previously, but River still seemed comfortable, retaining possession calmly. But then, in injury time, David Trézéguet, who looked far from fully fit, attempted an optimistic volley. His shot was blocked, Paredes came away with it and initiated a rare move of quality in a largely patchy game. He advanced into the River half, waited for support and spread the ball right to Chavez, whose cross was flicked on by Silva for Erviti to run on and poke past Barovero.

The silence round the bulk of the stadium was startling, while Boca at last – and surely even to their surprise – had something to celebrate.

A number of fans managed to clamber over the barbed-wire fence at the front of their section to dance on the concrete roof that prevented them lobbing missiles at the River fans beneath. It took almost an hour for them to be cleared, to the intense irritation of the home fans who, according to Argentinian regulations, can't leave the ground until the away fans are safely out of the way.

As they left, Boca's fans left a trail of minor destruction. Car windows were smashed and the letter B was daubed on walls and the windows of shops and cafes. The spectacle of the superclásico is astonishing but it's hard not to wonder whether the darker undertones are inevitable: can that level of passion exist without a certain amount of violence?

Elsewhere over the weekend, almost unreported, Newell's Old Boys maintained their excellent form to beat the champions, Arsenal, maintaining their unbeaten start to the season and keeping the gap to second-placed Vélez Sarsfield at three points.

Shares in gold miner Centamin plummeted more than 50% before being suspended after an Egyptian court ruled that the contract for the company's flagship Sukari gold mine in the country was void.

A judge said it was invalid and a further decision to offer a 30-year contract to allow it to be renewed was also void. The mine, not far from the Red Sea coast near Marsa Alam, is joint-owned with the Egyptian government.

The company attempted to allay fears, saying the mine remains operational.

It said

Comments reportedly made by an Egyptian administrative court this morning have given rise to speculation that parts of the Concession Agreement may have, in fact, been suspended. However at this time, no details of a final decision are available and no written judgement has been given.
Centamin confirms that it is not a party to this case, repeats its view that the concession as law 222 of 1994 remains valid and that the court does not have jurisdiction to cancel it. The Company will inform the market further as soon as more information is available. In the meantime normal mining operations continue.

Centamin are the latest in a number of companies being hauled before the courts over contracts signed with the previous Mubarak regime.

A lawyer, Hamdy Fakharany, who filed the case against Centamin claiming the returns to the government were not high enough, told Reuters:

The ruling brings back Egypt's gold back [home].
We will take an official copy of the ruling and inform the government, the mine should be closed now. This is a very positive ruling in favour of the Egyptian people.

Shares were temporarily suspended at 10am trading at 56p.

The subway is flooded and will take 4-5 days at least to return on line, officials advised. 80 homes burned down in coastal Queens. Scene of destruction on the New Jersey coast

The Guardian's Adam Gabbatt is in New Jersey:

Driving into Asbury Park, the scale of the damage from Sandy is not immediately apparent. People are without power, and a few trees are down, but they have homes.

In Loch Arbour, a tiny community neighbouring Asbury Park, it's a different story. A row of six houses that once proudly faced out to the Atlantic has been decimated by the storm.

One of the homes, a two-storey wood-panelled building painted pink, is missing almost its entire ground floor. On one side the front wall has been swept away. Inside furniture is entirely missing too, replaced by three feet of sand. The back wall is also gone, with the surge having swept clean through the house and across two gardens behind. The home only has one full supporting wall left and has been cordoned off by police.

Bill Gleeson, a funeral home director, owns the home next door. He's lived there with his family since 1986. His home has been more fortunate, most of the walls are intact, although inside there are water marks up to 5ft high in places. The floor is covered in a thick layer of sand.

"The water just washed right through," Gleeson said.

In Loch Arbour, West Rekeda, 47, manager of Kassin Beach club, also said the ocean “came right through the building”.

The club is closer to the beach than the houses. There's not much left of it. The back wall is still intact but the interior of the one-storey white building has been swept away. Individual planks are missing from the large blue porch, leaving it looking like a cattle grid. All the walls at the front of the structure are missing.

“It’s sad. So many good memories there,” Rekeda said. “We knew it was going to be bad but I didn’t think it was gong to be this bad.”

A police officer said no one had been injured, but no one will be returning any time soon.

This little row of houses seems to have borne the brunt of the storm on this stretch of coast, with damage more limited in either direction. The main problem for the fire department on Tuesday afternoon was towing cars off the beach, as gawkers headed down to the coast to survey the damage.

"Extremely windy but we were pretty blessed not to get the rain because that would have made it a lot worse," said Virginia Ferraro, whose husband was engaged in digging out a fire rescue van that had got stuck trying to help out the driver of a white sedan.

"It was crazy windy," she said, but she suffered no damage to her property. "But they warned us, they did a good job of warning us."

Ferraro didn't have power, but had made chilli on the stove. "It was pretty good," she said.

Staff at the New York University hospital, one of the city's largest, are investigating the power outage which sparked the evacuation of more than 200 patients, including critically ill newborn babies, beginning on Monday night.

Problems with telephone service meant that the families of patients were not being called to inform them that their relatives had been moved, the hospital said. It was left to the receiving hospitals, among them Mount Sinai and Sloan Kettering, to inform them, according to the hospital.

On Tuesday, a spokesperson for the hospital said the facility, which has eight different generators, including one on a higher floor, was still trying to assess what went wrong.

The spokesman told Stacey Sager from WABC that they do not think all eight went out but if in fact some are still working, it is not enough to power the whole hospital.

NYU didn't anticipate such heavy flooding from Sandy, the massive storm that hit the coast on Monday. They decided not to evacuate all patients before the storm, in contrast to the procedure carried out by Irene as it did with a year ago, according to CNN.

Dr Andrew Brotman, senior vice president and vice dean for clinical affairs and strategy at the hospital told CNN that, between 7 and 7.45pm on Monday the hospital's basement, lower floors, and elevator shafts filled with 10 to 12 feet of water and the hospital lost its power.

"Things went downhill very, very rapidly and very unexpectedly," Brotman said. "The flooding was just unprecedented."

Emergency generators began, he said, but two hours later, about 90% of that power went out, and the hospital decided to evacuate patients, beginning with those critically ill.

One report, from CBS News, said that the second backup device, on a low floor, was disabled by the water, while the primary backup, on the roof, was disabled when a fuel pump on a lower floor was flooded.

Four of the newborn babies were on respirators which were breathing for them and when the power went out, each baby was carried down nine flights of stairs while a nurse manually squeezed a bag to deliver air to the baby's lungs.

The hospital usually has about 800 patients, but hundreds of patients were discharged over the weekend in anticipation of the storm.

Fifty-two people died in Haiti and 200,000 were left homeless when Hurricane Sandy passed by the Caribbean country at the end of last week. Paul Owen has been talking to Lisa Laumann, Save the Children’s country director for Haiti, about the effects of the Hurricane there.

What we saw during tropical storm Isaac and I think in tropical storm Sandy as well is a government that is challenged by the recurrent disasters that hit the country but also a government that is increasingly able to deal with this type of disaster. Difference between hurricane and post-tropical storm

The National Hurricane Centre issued a useful explanation (pdf link) of the difference between a hurricane and a post-tropical cyclone.

It is not to do with its strength but rather with where it is taking its energy from. Sandy has taken on the structure of a wintertime low-pressure area, so is no longer a tropical cyclone.

The NHC says:

The primary difference between a tropical cyclone and a wintertime cyclone is the energy source. Tropical cyclones extract heat from the ocean and grow by releasing that heat in the atmosphere near the storm center. Wintertime cyclones (also called extratropical or frontal
lows), on the other hand, get most of their energy from temperature contrasts in the atmosphere, and this energy usually gets distributed over larger areas. 

Because of these differences, tropical cyclones tend to have more compact wind fields, tend to be more symmetric, and have a well-defined inner core of strong winds. Wintertime lows have strong temperature contrasts or fronts attached to them, have a broader wind field, and more complex distributions of rain or snow.

Disability and abortion are two words not without a creeping discomfort. More so, when put together. The latter recently reared its head; casual calls to draw back a woman's right to choose are now familiar in their cyclicality. The Tory minister for women Maria Miller, for her part, would like to reduce the abortion time limit to 20 weeks. Despite the fact that this is the point when many foetal abnormalities are detected, Miller, the former minister for disabled people, made no mention of what it would mean for women whose 20-week scan showed their child would have a disability. She either hadn't thought it through or didn't much care.

Some people seem to care, often more than they should. Last month, an alliance of "pro-life" campaigners and religious groups launched a campaign to ban the termination of pregnancies on the grounds of disability. The Paralympics – with its "astonishing examples of courage and triumphs over disability" – they said, highlighted the "contradiction" in the current abortion law.

The contradiction they refer to is that while the Abortion Act 1967 sets a 24-week limit on having an abortion, when there is "substantial risk that if the child were born, she or he would have physical or mental abnormalities as to be seriously handicapped", there is no limit. There are good reasons for that – medicine, practicality and basic human empathy.

Last year, out of the almost 190,000 abortions in England and Wales, 146 of them were after the 24-week point. However, the percentage of couples who choose an abortion after discovering their baby will have Down's syndrome is routinely 90%. For some, being told their child will have a severe disability is reason enough not to go ahead with the pregnancy. Worse (if certain moral judgments are to be applied), this is sometimes the case for pregnancies resulting from IVF that, before the word "disabled" was uttered, were much wanted.

Those trying to ban abortions on disability grounds claim that this is "eugenics", a form of "disability discrimination". And they think a sporting event that displays the most physically able disabled people tells us all we need to know about disability and, while we're at it, a woman's decision-making process. These are campaigners who reduce the nuances of disability to an insulting level, yet speak as if they are saving us from being wiped out, and we should be grateful.

There are times when abortion is the humane choice. In reality, there are times when people feel they simply cannot cope. It's OK to say that out loud. The thought doesn't suggest a disabled life is worth less, but acknowledges the extra time, energy and money a severely disabled life needs. Right now, there are parents of disabled children who are having to skip meals to pay the gas bill. There are disabled children who aren't getting the childcare, schools, therapies or even healthcare they need. If aborting a disabled foetus makes you uncomfortable, perhaps that should too.

It's convenient to judge the individual choosing the abortion. Truth is, many make their choice based on the conditions of society. To care about disability means working to make these changes, not using it as a smokescreen to take women's rights.

I've always regarded cashflow as the lifeblood of our business. My top 10 lessons are:

1. Managing cash is a priority. I like the adage that making a loss kills you slowly but running out of cash kills you instantly.

2. We watch cash like a hawk. I check the current account balance several times a week.

3. We have built a business that generates cash. We have focused on generating monthly recurring revenue.

4. "Choose your customers carefully" is good advice. We credit check them every time.

5. We used to see invoicing as a monthly activity. Now we invoice almost every day.

6. Credit control is a must for us. Any delinquent payers get daily attention.

7. We get rid of bad payers if we can't convert them into prompt payers.

8. We set credit control targets: no more than 40% of debts over 30 days, 10% over 60 and 4% over 90 days. The spreadsheet turns red if any limit is broken.

9. We have a clear written procedure for action on credit control: more than 30 days it's a statement and phone call. More than 60 days they are on hold and a legal letter goes out. Seven days later it's legal action.

10. If we need to take legal action we do it ourselves. If it's a straightforward claim we go to http://www.moneyclaim.gov.uk/.


Malcolm Newdick is the managing director of Riverbank IT Management

As beautiful illicit guilty pleasures go watching BBC2′s The Thick Of It is not exactly an out-of-control gambling habit.

A satirical fly-on-the-wall Yes, Minister for the 21st century, civil servants and politicians scheme, plot and manipulate obsessed by the whims of public opinion.

Chief among them is the figure of Malcolm Tucker. Like 'Iago with a blackberry' as the Spectator calls him in the programme itself, he is the government's director of communications whose Machiavellian command of the dark arts of spin is directly drawn from the underworld. Nothing is too low.

"Congratulations on your first confirmed kill," he chillingly writes on a card to a junior who ill in hospital goes along with his plot to unseat the leader of the opposition. Out of the box drifts a helium balloon with a picture of the deposed leader sellotaped to it. A perfect blend of malice and slapstick.

Watching the programme is also a secret vice of comms people to talk of the programme in hushed tones.

A few years ago the subject of The Thick Of It came up in a conversation I had with someone who had worked at the heart of government in the civil service. "On a good day it was nothing like it," the individual said. "On a bad day it was actually a toned down documentary."

Yet, part of me thinks people will look back in years to come and find that Malcolm Tucker is a bygone relic. Obsessed with newspaper headlines and able to cajole the priesthood of journalists with bribes and threats.

Or maybe the government comms people of the future will be just as frenetic and just as twitchy about public opinion. It's just that it'll be the bloggers and the digital journalists they'll be obsessed about.

The fourth series ended with Tucker disgraced, chased by a press pack from a police station after handing himself in to be arrested after he perjured himself at a public enquiry.

And Malcolm Tucker, to use a very Malcom Tucker word, 'is damaging'.

Why damaging?

Because he forms people's warped idea of what a public sector comms person looks like. Which is why he needs to be brought down from grace. It's why he needs to die. Under a bus. Outside parliament. With a single bunch of flowers from his ma in Scotland. Leaving a stack of cracking YouTube clips as his legacy.

Comms, like journalism, is a broad church and across it finds all sorts of characters and practices. Yet there is nothing I find in what he does remotely similar to what I do working in an environment that encourages open access to social media and open data. Central government people may disagree.

But as Alastair Campbell, the man who did most to create the late 20th century idea of a spin doctor, said recently the landscape has changed: "You can't dominate the news agenda now. The agenda is more chaotic but that's a good thing."

A new wave of so-called 'City Deals' has just been announced by the Government in which 20 cities and their wider areas will be given the opportunity to bid for radical new powers to boost local growth.

This involves the Government devolving powers in exchange for responsibility for delivering growth locally and includes the ability to 'earn back' tax from the Treasury as well as devolved transport budgets and control of the skills budget for each city.

This new wave includes several cities in the north of England: Hull and the Humber; Preston and Lancashire; Sunderland; and the Tees Valley – adding to existing City Deals in Leeds, Liverpool, Newcastle and Sheffield and the first of them all in Greater Manchester which set the benchmark for those announced today.

A key theme of City Deals is the need to have economic growth. Whilst this remains a driver for national and local government, solely concentrating on economic outputs severely limits potential to invest in communities and effectively tackle some of the long-term and structural inequalities that people face. For instance, such an approach can potentially exclude areas that form a critical portion of the non-market economy.

There must be a balance between the two. Successive investment and regeneration have changed the physical structures of place, yet entrenched social policy problems remain for some sections of the communities that live there. In order to address this, we need to involve all those that live in communities to best support the potential capabilities in a way that can drive social regeneration within some of our most consistently deprived communities.

The Social Action & Research Foundation, a new think-tank based in Salford which co-produces policies to eradicate poverty (of which I am a co-Director alongside Amina Lone), proposes the idea of Hot-Housing Public Policy; this is a new way of evidencing, shaping and delivering public policy that draws upon the range of expertise and knowledge of those that live and work in communities. In turn this will lead to more co-produced public services, which are effective and efficient and that deepen democratic accountability.

The City Deals provide a unique opportunity to be able to deliver this, but it requires some creative thinking. Successful innovation in one area will not be directly transferable to others, and will require local reinterpretation. Therefore, the City Deals should put in place commissioning and performance frameworks that enable local innovation to flourish, whilst maintaining the necessary monitoring that is required in order to assess effectiveness.

It is important to provide the necessary space whereby policy ideas can be nurtured within the local communities that they are rooted. In order to achieve this, City Deals could provide a skeleton framework as well as a support function that will allow the strategic and coordinated measures that are necessary. Alongside this, it is important to ensure adequate safety mechanisms and a level of quality assurance and standards across the board. However within this framework, communities must be given greater voice within local decision-making processes to be able to implement interventions and deliver co-produced services at a local level that are more in tune to local needs.

A coordinated approach will then be necessary to propagate the more successful innovations by supporting their replication to each locality, while allowing for a flexibility that can meet the specific needs and challenges of the area. This allows a basic framework with a universal policy approach to provide equitable delivery of services, whilst ensuring the flexibility for each co-produced project to be cross-fertilised with local expertise.

The development of innovations in public policy and its implementation in each City Deal area will then grow organically. This builds upon the successful and creative interventions that have already occurred, whilst providing more space, ownership and empowerment for such innovations to flourish, while providing the necessary frameworks to ensure the needs of all our diverse guarantees are met. Through such an approach, City Deals can help to contribute to increased localism within our communities in a way that creates efficient, effective and equitable public services.

Dan Silver is director of the Social Action and Research Foundation based in Salford. He Tweets on @DanSilverSARF.

If you want to be a successful teacher and conquer behaviour management I've heard you shouldn't smile before Christmas. Last week my PGCE course was compared to turkey rearing in as much as my fear of an unruly class was compared to that of a turkey's fear of 25 December as neither of us will be prepared for the full horror of what we will face. However, I am hoping I will still have a smile and at least a few feathers intact by the time Santa arrives.

Training to be a teacher is confusing. We are supposed to plan all our lessons, but ensure we are flexible and above all have other ideas. We are supposed to be friendly with the students, but not too friendly and not too strict either. We are supposed to teach them our expertise, but not spoon-feed too much and teach them life skills, not just teach for exams, but of course, while we're not teaching for exams, they have to get a C or above. Also what is it with education and shortening words? I got my CRB check, in order for me to start my PGCE and not the GTP, ITT or SCITT. I am learning about KS3, GCSE, AS and A2, with other supportive people such as the SMT, TAs, ASTs, EWOs, and SENCOs in order for me to achieve QTS and be an NQT in which case I will most likely try and avoid Ofsted and any other acronyms I may come across.

I have realised during the last few days that unfortunately my future career is also in the hands of the media. Students love stereotypical teachers. I have already been asked if my water bottle is filled with vodka, not water, due to Waterloo Road. I observed a Kes style PE lesson and everyone knows the supply teacher who thinks she is Professor McGonagall from Hogwarts. Personally, I'm sure I would prefer to work in a school similar to Rydell High, Grease style, where the students sing down the stairs instead of race and a leather jacket is much cooler than a blazer, right?

So far it has been intense, but exciting. I have spent a few days at my first placement school, which was lovely, despite the fact I was mistaken for a new sixth form student. Trust me, I have my power heels ready and have considered sticking my staff badge to my forehead. I have been warned in a kind of nice-ish Trinny and Susannah way, what not to wear. No socks with sandals (as if I would anyway), no cartoon ties (oh please), no blue hair (or any other artificial colour for that matter) and no visible undergarments. Enough said. My poor friend has already been labelled The Birdwatcher by her students, due to owning two items of clothing with a form of bird print on them.

I am aware stress is on the horizon and have been told at least 30 times that this is going to be the hardest year of my life. But, I am armed with my Kalms and have a stack of Cadbury's at the ready. On Thursday a rather self-assured, year 9 girl asked me: "Why on earth did you want to be a teacher miss?" I told her, because I enjoyed school and I want my students to enjoy it too. She smiled and said: "Ahhhhh miss, that's nice, no teacher ever says that. Are you a fun teacher, or do you just think you're a fun teacher?" "I'm a really fun teacher," I insisted with a fresh-faced trainee teacher look. "What do you teach miss?" she asked. "French and German," I proudly said. What I then received was a look of pure horror and confusion. It appears that according to year 9 the words "French" and "fun" do not often occur in the same sentence. Challenge set. Some may say I'm naive, I guess I'll soon find out.

Charlotte Derrett graduated in French, German and media and is studying for her PGCE at Newcastle University.

What's the first thing you do when you're marketing a production?

Paula Rabbit, head of press: When we begin to work on a press campaign one of the very first things we do, other than read the script, is talk to the director – find out what their vision for the show is because they are a mine of information about the play's background. If it's a new play, talk to the writer and find out what inspired them; very often their inspiration can make a great media pitch. Find out as much as you can from the actors too. What is particularly important in regional theatre is any sort of regional connection – local papers love a local angle.

Once we have all this information we write a press strategy, which can be incredibly specific: it details what the media pitch might be; what newspapers or websites it would be a good fit for; who we should approach and when we should do it. Photos are also really important so working into our plan when we'll have those is vital. Things change all the time so it's important the strategy is a working document.

Nick Boaden, head of marketing: Read the script, talk to the director and the writer (where possible – research the writer when not) to fully understand the production. We will often chat about our existing audiences and find "ways in" so that the director's creative vision will make sense to those audiences. We're not in the business of "persuading" people to see something they're going to get nothing out of – that helps absolutely no one.

If it's an existing and well known script (Cat on a Hot Tin Roof for example) then we'll be sharing research sources and spending time on Google. A great part of being such a busy theatre is that we tend to become really hot on one subject for the planning period, and into production, and then move on to something new. So in the space of a month, "all you need to know about Beckett" becomes "James Bourne – who is he?"

How can theatres outside of London attract national press to their performances?

Paula: I honestly don't think there are any standard do's and don'ts. What I think is important is to build a relationship with as many journalists as you can – not every conversation or visit or email needs to be about gaining column inches or securing a review. Begin to build up the trust between you and your key contacts so that when you send in your pitch, they'll be more likely to take a look.

Don't do 'trawler fishing' pitches – by that I mean don't pitch everything to everyone. Be very selective and trust your instincts as some ideas will be a better fit for certain journalists. You also need to know when you have chased a pitch enough; I suspect there is nothing more frustrating than having five phone calls a day from a very persistent press office when you're on deadline.

What we in the regions don't have is the luxury of being geographically close to some of the UK's key arts journalists, but don't be afraid to invite them to your theatre. If you know they're attending a press night, suggest they get an earlier train and come and have dinner with you first, or a quick backstage tour or tea with your artistic director.

I guess another tip would be to call when your press night is fast approaching – a quick personal reminder for them to add your show into their list is good. If there are other shows opening in your region then be willing to be a bit flexible with dates so that critics can hit more than one production on a single trip. That said, it's also really handy to keep up with your colleagues in other theatres in the area.

What's the key to keeping a well-known show like Cat on a Hot Tin Roof fresh and interesting to audiences?

Su Matthewman, director of communications: Ensuring that one of the reasons we're producing it in the first place is that it's relevant for audiences today, and that there are issues and themes within it that are pertinent to the society we live in. And then drawing on these for external messages to audiences, so that the reasons for doing the show in the first place are absolutely clear and understandable.

Paula: I think it's about reminding people that the show's themes are as relevant today as they were when the play was first produced. Interestingly I think Michael Billington in his historical piece references the fact that even though Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is thought of as Williams' greatest play, it isn't actually performed that often.

Getting people to chat about the show also really makes a difference – Twitter responses for our production of Cat have been great and sparked some really interesting conversations.

A mother who has admitted killing her two babies at her home in Wandsworth, south London, has told a court that she is "truly sorry" and thought she was a "good mum".

Felicia Boots, 35, pleaded guilty to the manslaughter of 10-week-old Mason and his 14-month-old sister, Lily, on 9 May on the grounds of diminished responsibilty. Boots had faced murder charges but the plea of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility was accepted by the prosecution.

Boots, who lived with her investment banker husband in a salubrious area of London – referred to as "nappy valley" because of the number of couples with infants there – at the time of the children's deaths, has been unable to attend two previous hearings after being detained in a psychiatric unit.

Wearing a black suit and white blouse at the Old Bailey, she began crying as she was asked to stand and enter pleas on the two murder charges.

She pleaded not guilty to murder, but guilty to manslaughter because of diminished responsibility, on both counts.

She sent a note to the court which was read by her counsel, Kate Bex, which read: "9 May 2012 is a day I will be eternally sorry for. It should never have happened. It troubles me more than anyone will ever know. Part of me will always be missing. I am a good person. I am a good mum and I never meant any of this to happen. I am truly sorry."

Edward Brown QC, prosecuting, told the court that it was not dealing with a murder, but a tragedy. "This plainly is a tragic case," he said.

The Crown had closely examined the medical evidence and spoken to Boots's husband, Jeff, who was in court, he added. "The authors of the reports are clear and agreed in their conclusions as to Boots's condition as at 9 May and the reasons for her actions on that day. As a result the Crown has taken the firm view that it is not in the public interest to pursue the counts of murder but to accept the pleas as entered."

Boots was ordered to be detained at a psychiatric unit and the court was told she would be given full support and care if she became pregnant again.

The judge, Mr Justice Fulford, said: "A prison sentence would be wholly inappropriate in this case." He added: "This is an almost indescribably sad case.

"Although the results of Mrs Boots's actions were profoundly tragic given the loss of two young lives, what occurred was not criminal activity in the sense that expression is normally understood.

"I unreservedly accept that what she did to the two children, that she and her husband loved and nurtured, were the results of physical and biological factors beyond her control."

There was no doubt of the strength of the relationship between the couple. "This has always been a happy family," he said. "This is someone who delighted in being a mother and she was good at it."

He said Boots may have hidden the extent of her mental anguish from her husband and family. The judge did not impose any restriction on the time Boots would be detained. Her husband and his family said they did not wish to make any further comments about the case.

It is believed Boots was suffering from severe postnatal depression when she killed her two children at the family's home. Her husband came home from work to find the two children lying side by side on the floor of a walk-in wardrobe. He called emergency services but the children could not be revived.

Unconfirmed reports suggest that Boots attempted to take her own life, but did not need medical attention. The formal cause of the children's death has not been confirmed but it is thought they were suffocated.

Judi Dench started life as M, the fictional head of MI6, by calling James Bond a "sexist, misogynist dinosaur". Oh how we cheered, us feminists sick of a long-running multibillion-pound franchise that left a series of beautiful women as little more than roadkill in the path of the spy we never loved. Seventeen years later, the great Dame seems to have left us with a film, Skyfall, we can all cheer. Or at least a proper female hero.

This statement may cause offence both to other feminists and die-hard fans who have long maintained that us laydeez can just go and talk on the phone while they enjoy the ultimate in male fantasy. Feminist author Bidisha once said: "Ian Fleming hates women and I don't buy into anything to do with that. The Bond films are generally sexist. I don't like anything that descends from a sewer of misogyny." And writer and broadcaster Fay Weldon said: "These characters were male fantasy figures. These films were attempts by men to keep women in their place and to ensure they still ironed their shirts."

The procession of women with ludicrous names (Pussy Galore: arf arf) and the patronising use of "girl", dreadful dialogue (some of which you can enjoy here) and ridiculous storylines have made me hate the whole idea of Bond. Until now.

The main cause for celebration is Judi Dench as M, the real hero of the film. Not only is she in charge but she shows both emotional power over her subordinates and human failure. She is no longer the joke older woman, there to act as the only foil to Bond's charms, but a real character with heroic traits.

When she first took the role in 1995 for Pierce Brosnan's Bond debut, GoldenEye, Dench's appointment was inspired by the rise to prominence of real-life MI5 boss Stella Rimington, who had recently become the organisation's first female director-general. Rimington retired in 1996, aged 61, after just four years in the top job. In Skyfall, Dench, who has had far longer in the fictional post, is judged to be past her best as the Whitehall mandarins try to edge her out. (I didn't miss the fact that the most hostile questioning from an ensuing committee-roasting comes from a female politician – as if the film's creators can't resist a bit of girl-on-girl action.)

Barbara Broccoli, one of the two co-producers, previously elicited derision when she called the Bond girls of the 60s "feminist role models" career women who were "sexual predators" giving as good as they got. With Judi Dench's M she has finally provided a role model. Without the sex. (I'm largely ignoring the oedipal overtones of Javier Bardem's villain.)

There are moments when the old Bond comes back in Skyfall. The film opens with a vehicle chase in which Bond laughs at Naomie Harris's driving skills (gasp, she knocks a couple of wing mirrors off while swerving at supersonic speed through rush-hour Istanbul) and then shows her less-than-sure aim with a gun. And, as Peter Bradshaw points out in his review, "the scene in which 007 steps suavely into the shower with delectable Sévérine (Bérénice Marlohe) could have happened at any time in the last half-century."

The backstory for Sévérine (spoiler alert), that of trafficking and abuse, also seems a bit of a turning point for Bond, although I'm no aficionado so forgive me if I'm wrong. Maybe the Bond women have all been victims of violence and I just wasn't listening while I shouted at the screen.

I can't help thinking that this shift in the position of women in the film (well, one film really) is part of the reason why Skyfall has had the biggest ever Bond opening and is on course to outpace 2006's Casino Royale (with $586m) as the most successful Bond film of all time at the box office.

Yet I'm sure many of the die-hard fans of the franchise will disagree. Even the Guardian's own Xan Brooks dissed the "touchy-feely indulgence" in Bond's childhood trauma and his relationship with a woman old enough to be (of course) his mother. "Don't they realise that 007 has always been at his most convincing when he's at his crudest and least adorned; when he's serving as a blank canvas for macho fantasy; the dark angel of our disreputable natures?"

I don't agree. I don't think it's good for boys or men to grow up thinking that misogyny and xenophobia are sexy (not to mention the idea that all baddies have a disability).

Perhaps my head was turned not on Saturday night when I saw Skyfall but 19 months ago when Dench and Craig teamed up to create the Equals video calling for equality. If you haven't seen it, watch it here.

In 2011, says the disembodied voice of Dench, a man is still likely to earn more for doing the same job and less likely to be judged for promiscuous behaviour. Hardly a ringing endorsement for a spy with money to burn and a string of lovers was it?

Some will argue that Bond is still awful for presenting a consumerist utopia where only the people with the money (to buy cars, computers, helicopters) can win. But that's a whole other piece. For now, will you join me in celebrating a sexy Bond with just a bit of the sexist left out?

The ruler of Qatar, Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, has been urged by a human rights organisation not to approve a media law that will compromise press freedom.

The New York-based Human Rights Watch (HRW) argues that the draft law contains penalties for those who criticise Qatar and its neighbouring governments.

It would create a double standard on free expression that is inconsistent with Qatar's claims to be a centre for media freedom in the region.

In 1996, Sheikh Hamad was responsible for setting up Al-Jazeera, the news network that has been so prominent in reporting popular uprisings in the Middle East.

But the draft law, which Qatar's legislative body approved in June 2012, would undermine press freedom, according to HRW.

Its deputy Middle East director, Joe Stork, says: "Instead of supporting press freedom, this draft media law is a commitment to censorship."

Even before the sheikh makes up his mind on whether to ratify the law, freedom of expression is already under pressure.

HRW points to the case of Qatari poet Muhammad Ibn al-Dheeb al-Ajami, who has been in prison for a year after five postponements to his trial on charges of "inciting the overthrow of the ruling regime," which carries the death penalty.

It appears that the charges relate to the fact that al-Dheeb recited a poem that appeared on the internet in August 2010 and included passages that insulted the emir.

Source: Human Rights Watch

As more business is conducted online, the ability to pitch – to present your product or service to a potential buyer – has become increasingly important. While your competitors are relying on their email marketing and websites, the person who gets out there and makes a real connection with the client is the one who sets the pace and captures the market. The same principles of pitching underpin both face-to-face sales and more traditional selling, and you can easily apply the tricks of multi-million pound marketing campaigns to increase your success rate.

Setting expectations

A pitch can be regarded as part of the product itself, much like the trailer for a movie is part of the emotional experience that the director wants to create. The pitch builds the expectations that the product itself then lives up to. An advert or a pitch no longer simply tells the customer the facts of the product; it influences how the customer feels about the product. The queues for the first iPads or iPhones formed long before anyone had actually held one, such was the strength of feeling generated by Apple's marketing campaign. When your pitch works as it should, your customers will experience something similar, already knowing how to feel about your product long before they take delivery of it.

Pitching for new business, therefore, isn't just a way to tell customers about your product, it's an integral part of it.

Your customers will begin to form their expectations long before you walk into their office to deliver the pitch. From their very first point of contact with you, they are making judgments and assumptions that all affect their perception of your pitch. The solution is to make that very first point of contact part of your pitch. This might be your first phone call to the customer, or it might be the moment that you shake their hand in the reception area. Don't bother with small talk or icebreakers, take every opportunity to influence the outcome of your pitch before your customer even realises you've started.

Setting the right goals

While pitching is arguably the most important business skill, it may also be the most dreaded. Not only is a fear of public speaking often part of the problem, there is a huge risk of failure associated with pitching.

Ask your colleagues about their goals for pitching and they'll likely say things like, "to win the deal". This is a completely unrealistic goal, because you can't control the client's decision, and you can't control your competitors. Instead, refocus on a goal that is totally under your control, such as "get my message across and check that the audience understands it". Whether that message is right for them is something you can't predict, but they will always respect someone who stands by their principles over someone who tries to hedge their bets.

Following up

It's very common for people to deliver an excellent pitch, only to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory through their behaviour afterwards. Hearing a "yes" at the end of the pitch isn't a cause for instant celebration; it's just one step in the overall business relationship. Let your customer know that they have made the right decision by keeping a professional and business-oriented attitude, and, as soon as you get back to your office, write a follow-up letter that reinforces the key points and reminds the customer of anything that you agreed. If the customer is yet to make a decision, reinforce your enthusiasm to work with them and ask for their business. After all, the customer knows that's why you pitched to them, so don't be afraid to say it.

The more that business is conducted online, the more customers value genuine, personal relationships. In a world of increasing choice, we turn to people we trust to help us to make decisions. When your competitors are content to wait for their websites to do the work, you'll find yourself streets ahead by getting out there, making real connections and pitching for new business.

Paul Boross is a communications expert who runs the online service The Pitch Doctor. He is author of The Pitching Bible.

Have you ever hidden under your duvet as you read that Count Olaf is creeping towards the Baudelaire children? Or jumped at the slightest creak or noise as Voldemort draws his wand against Harry? Or even had to check that your bedroom door is firmly shut as the White Witch cackles as she turns people into stone?

It's coming up to that spooky time of year again; when witches fly, zombies rise and Dracula asks to be invited in. While some fictional characters may make us jump out of our skin, we do love them (kind of). Let's face it, Red Riding Hood venturing into a deep, dark forest where NOTHING happens to her would would make for a very boring read. She may as well have just popped down out to the cornershop to buy a pint of milk. We need suspense, excitement, shock and fear!

The first time I remember being scared stiff was as I was reading Roald Dahl's The Witches. I hid under my cover with a lamp and read and read as the Grand High Witch declared her plan to the world's witches. What was I going to do? And who could I trust? Was anyone I knew a witch? Since then I have both loved and hated scary books - the feeling that my heart is racing and that every noise could be some terrible being creeping around my house makes me feel both petrified and exhilarated!

While there may be a lot of frightening female characters - Cruella de Ville, Mrs Coulter, the White Witch, Bellatrix Lestrange, to name just a few - I think that at least you know you could defend yourself if you bumped into one. The same goes for vampires (stake through the heart), or werewolves (silver bullets - they may be hard to come by, but goodness me are they worth it!), and zombies (just cut the head off). But I think the scariest thing of all is not being able to protect yourself, which is why I think that the death eaters are perhaps one of the scariest race of creatures. The float about, swooping down to feast on innocent victims' souls. Unless you're friends with Harry Potter there is nothing you can do. Just think, you could never hang out with your friends anymore, go for a swim or even read another book. You'd just be an empty body - eek!

While there are a lot of hair-raising characters out there, Halloween wouldn't be Halloween without getting a bit out of breath, breaking into a cold sweat and screaming as someone opens the door after reading some spooky stories told by torch light! This Halloween, why not read Edgar Allen Poe's tale, The Black Cat, a gruesome and eerie tale about a man who goes mad. Or try Bram Stoker's Dracula, the original vampire story. Reading it makes you feel like a (very unnerved) detective, as you sort through the diary entries, letters and ships logs, trying to make sense of the dark mystery. Or even try Shiver, by Maggie Stiefvater, a tale of forest creatures and human-werewolf love. But watch out for some of the scariest characters hidden in their pages!

Each creature is so different and terrifying in it's own way. So, we want to know which scary character is your favourite despite making your blood run cold? Email your suggestions to childrens.books@guardian.co.uk or tweet us @GdnChildrensBks and we'll publish your comments below.

Apple was in crisis on Monday as it revealed that the architect of its iPhone software, Scott Forstall, once tipped as a future chief executive, is leaving the company next year. John Browett, the retail chief poached from British chain Dixons only six months ago, is also going.

For those who have watched Forstall's ascent – pushed out, without doubt, by a ruthless Tim Cook as sure as if he were a misfiring supplier – it means one thing: no more "skeuomorphism".

Forstall had become infamous as the person within Apple who drove the use of computer interfaces that appeared like real-life objects, so that the iPad's calendar had a faux-leather appearance and deleting a ticket in the new Passbook app invoked a virtual shredder – which Forstall showed off with clear glee when launching the iPhone 5 in September. Now, it's his pass that's in the shredder.

Instead, Jonathan Ive (who has been at Apple longer even than Cook having joined in 1998) will be in charge of the "human interface" elements of the business – the first time that he has been put in charge of software as well as hardware.

There had been rumours that Forstall was in bad favour after he did not appear on stage at the launch of the iPad mini in San Jose last week – although he was present at the location on the day and was seen outside a nearby hotel after the launch.

The departure of retail chief John Browett will come as a relief to many in Apple's stores: staff disliked the measures he tried to put in place (until reversed by Cook) of making them profit-driven – something that they disliked in a culture which for 10 years had thrived on simply offering good customer service.

Cook had to step in earlier this year as dissatisfaction among retail staff grew over Browett's initiatives – which went against the practices that had been instilled since the first store was opened in 2001. The stores will be managed directly by Cook while the search for a new retail chief goes on.

Carolina Milanesi, smartphones analyst for Gartner, said: "I did question if Browett coming from Dixon was the right pick. Apple needs to learn how to deal with more customers in the stores but the need to retain the high level of care is something that a chain like Dixons does not do very well.

"Having Jonny [Ive] focus on human interface as well as design makes perfect sense to me. Design and user interaction need to be tightly integrated in order to deliver a richer experience. Bringing together the iPhone/iPad software, iOS and Mac OS makes perfect sense too, as devices like iPad, iPhones and Mac need to deliver similar experiences but not force users in behaviours that do not make sense."

There are two ways to view Monday's events: either Apple is in a downward spiral, having disappointed Wall Street last week for the second quarter in a row when it announced revenues and profits that grew less than had been predicted, notably due to a slowdown in iPad sales. Or Cook has decided to lance the boil as internal politics and dissent reached a key pitch, and he is now bringing in a reliable team to focus on the future – beyond the iPhone and iPad.

Forstall is thought to have been blamed for the maps fiasco that followed the launch of the iOS 6 software in September, where Apple's own product replaced Google's. Many customers complained at lack of accuracy in the data, forcing Cook to issue an apology and point users to other services from rivals including Nokia and Microsoft. Forstall was also responsible for the Siri "voice control" interface, which has had mixed success.

Apple said in a press release that the changes would "encourage even more collaboration between the company's world-class hardware, software and services teams". The lack of any thanks towards either Forstall or Browett suggests that Cook has acted ruthlessly as the company has seen slackening improvements.

The company is notoriously secretive, yet discourages internal politics in favour of working in small teams who focus on solving problems collaboratively. Browett's brief tenure is not the shortest of an incoming Apple executive, but it is embarrassing for someone who had won what had looked like one of the biggest jobs in retail.

The changes will see a four-way split in responsibilities. Eddy Cue, who for years built up Apple's presence in the music business as its iPod business grew, and who has been in charge of the iCloud services, will now take over responsibility for the Maps and Siri services.

He was praised by Cook for an "excellent track record" in "building and strengthening Apple's online services to meet and exceed the high expectations of our customers", possibly hinting that Forstall failed in the latter regard.

The desktop, smartphone and tablet software will be united under Craig Federighi – possibly hinting at longer-term integration between the two. And Bob Mansfield, who had been expected to retire earlier this year but was brought back by Cook, will lead a new "Technologies" group combining the teams working on wireless technologies with aims at high-level innovation.

Forstall was key in the development of the original iPhone software, leading a team which raced against another in-house group to try to produce the prototype code. Forstall's team was trying to "shrink" the code used on the Macintosh desktop system; the rival team was trying to "scale up" that used on the iPod, then the best-selling Apple product. Forstall's team won and he was seen as a potential heir to Steve Jobs – although others inside the company accused him of playing company politics.

He also worked on the original Mac OS X desktop software, having worked at the NeXT company that Steve Jobs created and which was bought by Apple in 1997 letting Jobs back in, where he led a revival of the business from near-bankruptcy.

Cook has shown a ruthless side in firing Browett. It is a move that reflects the way that senior managers at Apple are told they bear ultimate responsibility for what happens in their division.

Outcome-based commissioning has been an important feature of the adult social care landscape for some time. But to what extent are services really being commissioned on the basis of outcomes for the service user?

A new LGiU report, supported by social care provider Mears, examines the theory and practice of outcome-based commissioning in domiciliary care services.

LGiU research shows that nine out of 10 local government officers and elected members in social care regard commissioning for outcomes, rather than activities, as central to the future of the service. However, true outcome-based commissioning involves paying providers according to the outcomes they deliver for the service user, and progress on this front has been fraught with difficulty. Our initial survey found:

• While most respondents reported the regular use of outcome-based commissioning, just over a third said that it was only used "to a limited degree" in their authority.

• Three quarters of respondents said their current systems and processes would be insufficient to manage adult social care provision in future and said they regarded "a culture of running services on a time-task basis" as an important barrier to better commissioning.

• However, over 90% still pay providers according to the time they spend with a service user, rather than outcomes.

Further research highlighted a range of illuminating case studies. Among them, Wiltshire county council's "Help to Live at Home" scheme rewards and penalises providers on the basis of their performance against outcomes; Trafford's Quality Checkers show how successfully service users can be involved in improving service performance; while Essex county council demonstrates a useful model of market management and use of payment by results in reablement.

From these case studies we have developed a five-point checklist for raising our game in commissioning.

Are you contracting for outcomes?

Explicitly linking the payment of providers to the outcomes, rather than the outputs that they deliver, is a powerful tool. When providers are paid on an hourly rate, they are offered no incentive to reduce dependency on services or respond flexibly to individual changes in circumstance. Giving them the right target will help to improve the efficiency of the service and result in better outcomes for the individual.

Have you considered the local drivers for need?

Service user need can be manufactured by badly designed services. If we are to deal with the current pressures on adult social care, domiciliary care services should be based on the premise of reducing or stabilising dependence on service provision, wherever possible in line with service users' own expressed preferences.

How well aligned is your commissioning for housing, health and social care commissioning?

Housing, health and social care are the three pillars of independent living. Identifying shared outcomes between these three areas and commissioning together will offer more efficient and integrated services.

Do you empower providers?

The focus on a time-task method of commissioning, along with tight budgetary constraints and several high profile safeguarding scandals, have tended towards a command and control approach to dealing with providers. Commissioning for outcomes puts the onus on the provider to solve the problem, alongside the service user. Market management should be about increasing the range of care products available, rather than simply increasing the volume of providers in the market.

How engaged are elected members?

Councillors have a crucial role to play in connecting council processes to the outcomes they see through their case work in the community. Elected members can act as important advocates for people in the care system, while also holding influence over the internal processes for commissioning.

There is no one-size-fits-all model of service delivery that will provide the answers to the challenges facing social care.

However, by sharing practice we can move towards better models of outcome-based commissioning that support cost-effective, person-centred services in times of great financial pressure.

You can read the full report from the LGiU, Outcomes Matter: effective commissioning in domiciliary care online here.
